musicalLanguage.description: One of the most covered songs in history, originally performed with a string quartet. The melody is singable and poignant, moving through F major with surprising chromatic touches. This simplified arrangement focuses on the vocal melody with basic chord support.
musicalLanguage.structure: Verse (8 bars) — F-Em7-A7-Dm-Bb-C-F progression with melodic narrative
keyMoments: Bars 1-2: F major opening — the melody immediately establishes the wistful mood
Bars 3-4: A7 to Dm — the harmonic surprise that gives the song its distinctive color
Bars 7-8: Bb-C-F cadence — the classic resolution that brings the verse home
teachingGoals: Playing a lyrical melody with proper phrasing
Basic chord shapes in F major: F, Dm, Bb, C
Understanding how melody and harmony work together
styleTips: Play the melody as if you were singing it — breathe where a singer would
Left hand should be gentle and supportive, never overpowering
Slightly slower than strict tempo feels right — let it be nostalgic

measures.teachingNote: F major — the melody begins on the third degree. Simple, direct, unforgettable.
Em7 to A7 implied — the melody descends smoothly. Notice the E natural in the bass.
D minor — the relative minor. The melody rises F-G-A, a hopeful gesture.
Bb to C — the melody mirrors the rise with a fall. Classic arch-shaped phrasing.
Back to F — the second phrase begins with ascending energy.
Same harmonic motion as bar 2 — the symmetry is what makes this melody stick.
Bb to C — melody descends to the depths. This is the emotional low point.
F major — the melody lands on the tonic. Hold it and let the sadness settle.
